Install SaltStack

You'll learn how to:

  • Install SaltStack
  • View and accept connections from managed systems
  • Send a test command to all managed systems

Estimated time: 10 minutes

Difficulty:

To install SaltStack, you’ll need a detailed network diagram with your complete DNS mappings, an enterprise database server, and yeah, you don’t need any of that stuff. All you need is a way to install packages on your systems, and about 10 minutes.

You can install SaltStack from a package manager, pip, directly from source, or using a bootstrap script. We’ll assume that you already have a favorite installation method, given that you’ve been using it daily to install and update packages manually.

You can get the details on your favorite method in the docs, but the simplest way is to use the bootstrap script. This script installs SaltStack with a couple of commands on most operating systems.

Terms

Master: the central management system.

Minion: a managed system.

Architecture 101

On the master

Run this command on the system that you want to use as the central management point.

curl -L https://bootstrap.saltstack.com -o install_salt.sh
sudo sh install_salt.sh -M

On each minion

Run this command on each system that you want to manage using Salt.

curl -L https://bootstrap.saltstack.com -o install_salt.sh
sudo sh install_salt.sh

'salt' hostname

Minions must be able to contact the master using the 'salt' hostname. If you don't have DNS in your environment, or if the master hostname is something other than 'salt', you can add the IP address of your master server to the minion configuration file. huh?

sudo sh -c "echo 'xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx salt' >> /etc/minion"

Remember to replace xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx with something useful.

Accept Connections

Each connection between the Salt master and minion is managed and secured using cryptographic keys. After installation, each minion sends its public key to the master, where it eagerly waits to be accepted.

View all keys

On the master, you can quickly view all minion connections and view whether the connection is accepted, rejected, or pending.

salt-key --list-all

Accept a specific key

Before a minion can connect, you must accept its key.

salt-key --accept=<key>

Accept all keys

salt-key --accept-all

Send a Command

After you have accepted each key, send a command from your master to verify that your minions are listening:

salt '*' test.ping

If you don't see all of your minions respond, well that is what happens when you set things up manually. You probably typed something wrong, didn't accept some keys, or forgot to add a space somewhere (#soml). After your minions are all responding, continue to the next section to put Salt to work.
